markdownRemark.html:
I had to lead the way when I expected something from my team.

For example: If I wanted others to write tests, then first I had to write them and demonstrate that it’s a good practice to include tests in every pull request. Also Tests are your best friend. Having good number of tests in your codebase lets you onboard new people easily without having to worry about regressions. Those were the pre-corona times where the team was still not used to working remote, although we had a flexible work from home policy. Home office was difficult, or atleast was not ideal to decide to do home office the last minute, because there were now others waiting and me calling for a home office suddenly would mean they would be blocked. when taking holidays, inform multiple people Pivot person of contact Personal “productivity” had to be completely redefined. Enabling others to finish their tasks, or unblocking them was more important. Empathy has to be valued above output. Setting standards for your team starts with you (e.g., not sending emails after hours, etc) Sometime hard decisions - firing, being strict with managing Meetings get blocked

  • Lunch time meetings are favorite
  • teach concepts to two people at a time, other than you
  • don’t just delegate to one person
  • more accountable for mistakes.
  • setting example with your behaviour, etiquette
  • give credit to others wherever it’s due
  • lot of linkedin spams
  • anjali’s example —> me being angry with Paul

Habits:

  • clean emails
  • clean slack conversations
  • remember to follow up

We are hiring!
